Fig. 1 Diagram of the experimental setup used for catalytic activity evolution. (1) Xenon lamp device, (2) cutoff filter (400nm), (3) reactor, (4) magnetic beater, (5) lifting desk, (6) air, (7) peristaltic pump, (8) UV–vis or PL spectrophotometer, (9) invigilator. Fig. 2 UV–vis spectra, curve (1): HSiW aqueous solution; curve (2): UV-irradiated HSiW aqueous solution in the presence of propan-2-ol; curve (3): solution shown as curve (2) after addition of AgNO3 aqueous solution; curve (4): solution shown as curve (3) after stopping UV irradiation; inset is photos of the four solutions. Fig. 3 (a) XRD patterns of HSiW, AgSiW, and Ag/AgHSiW. (b) TEM image of Ag/AgHSiW NPs. Fig. 4 XPS spectra of the Ag/AgHSiW NPs. Fig. 5 FT-IR spectra (a) and TG plots (b) of HSiW, AgSiW, and Ag/AgHSiW catalysts. Fig. 6 UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectra (a) and PL spectra (b) of HSiW, AgSiW, and Ag/AgHSiW. Fig. 7 (a) Photocatalytic activity comparison of different catalysts. (b) The change of intensity of SPR peak (red curve) and concentration of MB solution (blue curve) as a function of visible-light irradiation time. Inset shows UV–vis spectral changes of MB aqueous solution in the presence of Ag/AgHSiW NPs under visible light irradiation. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of the article.) Fig. 8 (a) Cycling runs in the photodegradation of MB in the presence of Ag/AgHSiW NPs under visible-light irradiation. (b) Resonance light scattering spectra of Ag/AgHSiW NPs before and after photocatalytic reaction. Fig. 9 (a) Schematic diagram showing the energy band structure and electron–hole pair separation in Ag/AgHSiW NPs. (b) Time-dependent fluorescence emission spectra of 2-hydroxyterephthalic acid formed by the reaction of terephthalic acid with radicals. The inset shows the time-dependent fluorescence intensities of 2-hydroxyterephthalic acid at 426nm. Graphical abstract Highlights ► A new visible-light driven photocatalyst Ag/Ag x H4−x SiW12O40 was designed. ► This photocatalyst shows a high activity for the degradation of MB. ► The high activity could be attributed to the synergy of AgHSiW and Ag. A newly-designed polyoxometalate (POM)-based plasmonic visible-light catalyst, Ag/Ag x H4−x SiW12O40 (Ag/AgHSiW) nanoparticles (NPs), is prepared by a green photoreduction strategy without the addition of any surfactant. The Ag/AgHSiW NPs, which possess abundant hydroxyl (OH) groups on their surface, has not only significantly enhanced visible spectrum absorption but also reduced photoluminescence (PL) emission. Compared with P25, Ag NPs, H4SiW12O40 (HSiW) and Ag4SiW12O40 (AgSiW), the Ag/AgHSiW photocatalyst shows high photocatalytic activity and stability for the decomposition of methyl blue (MB) under visible light irradiation, which could be attributed to highly synergic effect of photoexcited AgHSiW and plasmon-excited Ag NPs. Keywords POMs Plasmonic Visible light catalytic MB 1 Introduction Water detoxification has become an environmental issue of ever increasing importance. Photocatalytic degradation used for purification of water is attracting more interest because photo-assisted catalytic reactions are generally carried out at atmospheric pressure and room temperature and hazardous organic pollutants could be photo-oxidized into nontoxic CO2, H2O, or inorganic anions rather than transferred into other media [1]. Many metal-oxide-semiconductor (MOS) materials, such as TiO2, Ta2O5, ZnO, etc., have been tested as photocatalysts [2–4]. But they are usually used only under UV irradiation due to their wide band gap. Therefore, the development of photocatalysts with a high activity under visible light (λ >400nm) is a great challenge. Several approaches for MOS modification have been proposed to extend the response of photocatalysts from the UV to the visible light region, which could be realized by doping metals (Cu, Fe, Ag, Pt, Au, etc.) [5,6] and nonmetals (C, N, F, S, etc.) [7,8] in conventional MOS photocatalysts to decrease their band gap to accommodate the visible-light photon energy. Another promising strategy is focused on developing new visible-light-driven photocatalysts with a relatively high activity, such as Sr1−x NbO3 [9], m-BiVO4 [10], β-AgAl1−x Ga x O2 [11], etc. However, these available materials to date are largely limited by either poor photocatalytic efficiency in the visible light range or poor stability in the photocatalytic reaction process. Plasmonic metal nanoparticles (NPs) are characterized by their strong interaction with resonant photons through an excitation of surface plasmon resonance (SPR), in which the resonant photon-induced collective oscillation of valence electrons is established when the frequency of photons matches the natural frequency of surface electrons oscillating against the restoring force of positive nuclei [12–14]. The resonant wavelength and SPR intensity depend not only on the intrinsic nature of the metal, but also on its size and shape. By manipulating the composition, shape and size of plasmonic metal NPs, it is possible to design nanostructures with light adsorption covering the entire solar spectrum and beyond. Numerous studies have revealed that plasmonic noble metal NPs (mainly silver and gold) show substantially enhanced visible light catalytic activity for the degradation of organic pollutants [15,16]. Despite these promising studies, the instability of noble metal NPs during the photocatalytic oxidization process has not been overcome to date. Therefore, how to solve this issue is a great challenge. Polyoxometalates (POMs) are unique early transition metal oxygen clusters, which have been proved to possess photochemical characteristics similar to MOS photocatalysts [17]. They are highly efficient oxidants that perform fast and reversible multi-electronic redox transformation under mild conditions whilst their structure remains intact. As a consequence, they can act as bifunctional catalysts providing an interesting route to the destruction of a great variety toxic and hazardous pollutants in the aquatic environment upon excitation with near-visible and UV light [18]. In view of above features, we consider the combination of the POMs with plasmonic noble metal NPs to rationally design a chemically and physically stable catalyst to obtain highly efficient use of solar energy. Such a conceptually novel strategy would provide catalysts with at least dual activity, offering new opportunities in organic chemistry by combining two or more chemical properties on the same POM catalyst. In the present work, a newly-designed POM-based plasmonic visible-light catalyst, Ag/AgHSiW NPs, were easily obtained by an innovative photo-reduction approach under mild conditions without the addition of any surfactant [19,20]. The as-synthesized catalyst exhibited good catalytic activity for the degradation of MB under visible light irradiation and photo-stable during photocatalytic reaction process. Different from other plasmonic photocatalysts Ag@AgX (X=Cl, Br and I), Ag/AgHSiW is photo-stable and cannot be photoreduced to Ag. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst synthesis The commercial H4SiW12O40 (HSiW) was dried at 373K for 3h to remove physisorbtion water before use, and all other chemicals used were analytical grade without further purification. Deionized and doubly distilled water were used throughout the experiments. In a typical synthesis, 1mL of isopropanol was added into 1000mL of 0.05mM aqueous solution of HSiW, and the mixture was first deaerated by Ar and then irradiated by UV light for 30min. Subsequently, under the UV illumination in Ar atmosphere, 2mL of 0.1M AgNO3 aqueous solution was injected to above solution and dark yellow colloidal mixture was obtained. After aged for 2 days, the colloidal mixture was collected by centrifugation, washed with water for several times. Finally Ag/AgHSiW NPs were obtained, which then were re-dispersed in water. The bare Ag NPs was prepared by the photo-assisted reducing of AgNO3 aqueous solution in the presence of isopropanol; AgSiW was obtained by the reaction of AgNO3 and HSiW with a stoichiometric ratio at room temperature and AgHSiW could be prepared by the reaction of AgNO3 and HSiW with a non-stoichiometric ratio at room temperature. 2.2 Characterization The composition and phase purity of the as-synthesized samples were analyzed by X-ray diffractometry (XRD) with monochromatized Cu-Kα (λ =1.54178Å) incident radiation by a Shimadzu XRD-6000 instrument operating at 40kV voltage and 50mA current. The morphologies and microstructures of the samples were examined with a JEM 2010F field emission gun transmission electron microscope operated at an accelerating voltage of 200kV. Fourier transformed infrared spectra (FT-IR) were recorded on a Thermo Nicolet iS5 spectrometer using KBr pellets. Thermogravimetry (TG) analysis was performed in the flow Ar at a heating rate of 5Kmin−1 using Shimadzu DTG-60AH system apparatus. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were carried out with an ESCALAB 250 electron spectrometer using a monochromatic Al Kα (hv =1486.6eV) source. All binding energies (BE) were referenced to the C 1s peak (284.6eV) arising from adventitious carbon. The ultraviolet–visible diffuse reflectance spectra (UV–vis DRS) of the samples were collected using a Shimadzu UV-3600 PC ultraviolet visible near-infrared spectrophotometer with BaSO4 as the reference material, and were converted from reflection to absorption according to the Kubelka–Munk method. The PL spectrum, at an excitation wavelength of 400nm, was recorded on a Hitachi F-4600 spectrofluorometer equipped with a double grating 0.22m Spex 1680 monochromator. UV–vis extinction spectrum was taken on a LabTech UV-power diode array spectrophotometer with an automatic sampling and monitoring for definite time. 2.3 Photocatalytic activity test Photocatalytic activities of the samples were assessed by monitoring the degradation of MB as a probe reaction under visible-light irradiation (λ >400nm). An automatic photocatalytic setup, as shown in Fig. 1 , was built for sampling and monitoring over definite time interval. Photocatalyst experiments were carried out in a jacketed vessel, and circulating water was used to remove infrared radiation and heat. The visible light was obtained by a 300W Xenon arc lamp with an UV cut-off filter (λ >400nm) to remove the undesired radiations, which was put above the jacketed vessel and the distance between the liquid surface and the light source was about 10cm. In a typical process for MB degradation, 1.5mL of 2gL−1 MB aqueous solution was added into 250mL of above catalyst colloidal solution and was stirred continuously in a dark condition for 1h to reach adsorption–desorption equilibrium between the photocatalyst and MB before irradiation. The air is continuously diffused into the reaction solution at a flow rate of 30mLmin−1 to supply the dissolved oxygen. The photo activity of the sample was then evaluated by monitoring the intensity of the strongest absorption peak of MB at 603nm on a UV–vis spectrometer along with definite time interval of irradiation automatically. For comparison, the photocatalytic activity of no catalyst, P25, Ag NPs, HSiW and AgSiW were also conducted under the identical experimental conditions. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis of Ag/AgHSiW The Ag/AgHSiW catalyst was prepared by a photoreduction method following five stages and the UV–vis spectrum was used to monitor every stage simultaneously, as shown in Fig. 2 . First the initial HSiW aqueous solution is colourless (bottle 1) and its absorption band cantered at 264nm is the characteristic of Keg gin-type POM, corresponding to Ob,c →W charge transfer transition (curve 1). The solution turned light blue (bottle 2) by photo-irradiation in Ar atmosphere, indicating that heteropoly blue (HPB) was generated by isopropanol reduction of HSiW [curve 2, Eq. (1-1)], which led to visible characteristic absorption peaks at 630 and 808nm. When the silver nitrate solution was injected into HPB solution during the illumination, the solution became yellow-green (bottle 3). Accordingly, the SPR of silver NPs was observed and the peak centered at 393nm [curve 3, Eq. (1-2)]. At the same time, the characteristic absorption peak of HPB still existed but its intensity decreased a little. Finally the solution appeared bright yellow (bottle 4) after Ar-shielding and illumination were removed (curve 4). The intensity of silver SPR peak decreased and that the absorption peak shifted from 393 to 400nm, which is probably due to that Ag NPs are partly oxidized by O2 in the air to form Ag+ [Eq. (1-3)]. The characteristic peak of HPB disappeared [Eq. (1-4)], indicating that HPB was reoxidized into HSiW by the oxygen in air. [Eq. (1-4)]. The un-reduced Ag+ could react with HSiW in the aqueous solution to form Ag x H4−x SiW12O40 [Eq. (1-5)] and thus Ag/Ag x H4−x SiW12O40 composite NPs were obtained. For comparison, those of parent HSiW and homemade AgSiW were also provided. According to literature, AgSiW and HSiW are isostructural and therefore their XRD patterns are undoubtedly similar [21], while the pattern of the as-synthesized catalyst is also similar to those of AgSiW and HSiW, indicating that the main component of the as-synthesized catalyst may be AgHSiW. The proton–metal ion exchange should exhibit dual and tunable catalytic properties, combining metallic and acidic functions [22]. Furthermore, compared to HSiW and AgSiW, the Ag/AgHSiW diffraction peaks are broad, indicating that the Ag/AgHSiW NPs are quite small. However, no characteristic diffraction peaks of metal silver are observed in the XRD profile of Ag/AgHSiW except the diffraction peaks of the AgHSiW, which is probably due to the uniform distribution of the small Ag NPs. TEM image of the Ag/AgHSiW is presented in Fig. 3(b). The TEM image clearly shows the polydispersed spherical NPs with diameters in the range of ca. 5nm. In addition, we also found by a high-magnification TEM (inset in Fig. 3(b)) that some NPs are interconnected. Because of the low contrast of Ag relative to AgHSiW NPs in the TEM image, it cannot be well distinguished from one to another in the present work. In order to further investigate and identify the valence state of Ag and W in the Ag/AgHSiW NPs, XPS measurements were performed in the electron binding energy (BE) regions corresponding to Ag3d (Fig. 4(a)) and W4f (Fig. 4(b)). The Ag3d 2/5 peak with BE located at about 368eV was asymmetric and it can be fitted into three peaks and their BE is 367.6, 368.3 and 368.8eV, respectively, indicating the presence of three silver species in Ag/AgHSiW NPs [23]. The highest peak at BE of 368.3eV can be ascribed to Ag+ in AgHSiW and its BE is slightly higher than that of the standard metallic silver reference (368.0eV). The reason should be attributed to the shorter bond between the silver ions and relatively weak interaction with the Keggin anions. The peak at the lowest BE of 367.6eV can be related to silver oxide while the one at the highest BE of 368.8eV can be assigned to metallic Ag and in our case it can also be called “subsurface” Ag, which may concentrate on the surface of AgHSiW NPs. Ag can strongly adsorb visible light due to its SPR, which will lead to the improved photocatalytic activity of AgHSiW NPs. For W4f XPS spectrum, two different electronic states of W4f 7/2 centered at electron BE of 35.3 and 36.1eV were observed. The first one is approximately equal to the literature value of W6+, which could be ascribed to SiW12O40 4− Keggin anions, in well agreement with the result reported elsewhere. The other peak at BE of 36.1eV indicates that a small part of Keggin units exists on the surface or in the sub-surface region due to the light irradiation. That is, POMs occur the charge transfer from O2− to W6+ under the light irradiation, leading to the formation of a pair of hole center (O−) and trapped electron center (W5+). The excited state POM* ([W5+ OW6+]*), has strong oxidation ability and it is responsible for the oxidation of organics into the inorganic products [24]. As well known, surface functional groups on the surface of catalysts have an important effect on their catalytic activity. Therefore the IR spectrum measurements were performed for the as-synthesized Ag/AgHSiW NPs together with the parent HSiW and the home-made AgSiW. As shown in Fig. 5(a), the typical Keggin anion skeletal vibration bands (νas) for HSiW mainly center at 1018, 978, 922 and 782cm−1, corresponding to SiOa (oxygenin central SiO4 tetrahedron), WOd (terminal oxygen bonding to W), WOb W (inter-octahedral), WOc W (inter-octahedral) [21], respectively. These characteristic bands are also observed in the spectra of AgSiW and Ag/AgHSiW, indicating that the Keggin structure is intact during the exchange of protons in the secondary structure of HSiW with silver ions. The band at 1615cm−1 corresponds to the vibration of non-protonated water molecule, indicating that the HSiW, AgSiW and Ag/AgHSiW all have water of crystallization. The peaks appearing at 537 and 477cm−1 are assigned to the vibration of δ (OSiO) and ν s (WOW), respectively. When the exchange of the H+ by Ag+, the intensity of the peak at 878cm−1 increases. This result provides the fact that the counter cations are linked to the bridging oxygen WOb W. Moreover, Ag/AgHSiW exhibits a new peak at 1415cm−1 compared to HSiW and AgSiW, which could be attributed to the fundamental frequency of the symmetric band vibration of δ(OH) [25,26]. According to literature, the presence of OH groups on the surface of catalysts is beneficial for photocatalytic reaction by forming hydroxyl radicals (·OH), which can significantly improve photocatalytic activity. IR analysis only indicates the existence of the chemically adsorbed water and OH groups, but their precise content cannot be provided. For this reason we have performed TG measurement of the catalysts to confirm the content variation of chemically adsorbed water and OH groups. Fig. 5(b) presents the TG curve of Ag/AgHSiW as well as those of HSiW and AgSiW. In the low temperature range of 373–573K, the mass loss of HSiW, AgSiW, and Ag/AgHSiW is about 3.12%, 1.55%, and 1.87%, respectively, which can be assigned to the loss of chemical adsorption water loosely bonded to the surface. At the temperatures above 573K, HSiW shows a mass loss of 1.07%, which could be attributed to the proton loss resulted from the decomposition of the skeleton of POMs, while almost no mass loss for AgSiW is observed since the protons were replaced by silver cations. However, the Ag/AgHSiW gives a mass loss of 2.04%, which is higher than that of AgSiW and even is twice that of HSiW. According to above IR spectrum of Ag/AgHSiW we know that no carbonate vibration was observed. Therefore the large mass loss above 573K confirms the fact that there are lots of OH groups existing on the surface of Ag/AgHSiW besides the protons. As a consequence, more OH might trap more photogenerated holes, efficiently improving the separation of photo-excited charge carriers [27]. Therefore, it can be expected that more OH groups on the surface of Ag/AgHSiW will contribute to its improvement of photocatalytic activity. Moreover, the loss temperature of the OH groups is above 573K, suggesting its quite strong bonds, the Ag/AgHSiW was strong Brønsted acid [22]. 3.3 Property characterization of Ag/AgHSiW Fig. 6(a) shows the UV–vis DRS of the Ag/AgHSiW sample as well as those of HSiW and AgSiW samples. The HSiW sample exhibits broad and strong absorption only in the UV region from 200 to 400nm, which is a typical characteristic of Keggin-type POMs. After H+ is replaced by Ag+, the spectrum of the as-resulting AgSiW shifts to a longer wavelength, which can be ascribed to the introduction of O→Ag energy level in the band gap of HSiW. The strong adsorption in the UV region and a weak absorption in the visible region were observed. The Ag/AgHSiW photocatalysts, besides in the range of UV, also exhibit strong absorption in the visible light region of 400–750nm, which could be ascribed to the SPR of Ag NPs [28]. This fact also further confirms the presence of Ag NPs in this compound. Therefore, the combining of AgSiW with Ag greatly extend and enhanced the light adsorption of catalyst in the visible light region. To further confirm that the introduction of Ag into AgHSiW can greatly reduce the recombination rate of photo-excited charge carriers, the PL spectra of these photocatalysts are measured (Fig. 6(b)). It can be clearly seen that with excitation at 400nm, HSiW and AgSiW catalysts both have an obvious emission quenching peak at 440–480nm in the PL spectra, while for Ag/AgHSiW sample, this peak decreases significantly, indicating low recombination rate of photo-excited charge carriers. The sharp decrease in PL intensity with light illumination could be ascribed to the fast transfer of the photogenerated electrons by the Ag NPs, which greatly reduce the recombination rate of photo-excited charge carriers. These results tell us that the Ag/AgHSiW sample has great potential to be used as a visible-light catalyst. 3.4 Catalytic activity of Ag/AgHSiW under visible-light irradiation MB can be easily activated by light to an excited state and shows a main absorption band centered at about 603nm. Here, we choose MB as target hazardous pollutant to evaluate the photocatalytic activity of the Ag/AgHSiW catalyst. For comparison no catalyst, P25 (commercial TiO2), Ag, HSiW and AgSiW are also studied under same conditions. As shown in Fig. 7(a), when no catalysts was involved, the degradation of MB was only 4.9% in 170min visible-light irradiation, nearly negligible, while the P25, Ag, HSiW and AgSiW photocatalysts showed 15.7%, 18.7%, 9.2%, and 12.4%, respectively, a little higher activity toward MB degradation. In contrast, Ag/AgHSiW sample showed 96.0% in the same conditions, exhibited significantly improved catalytic activity for the degradation of MB. This result is similar to other reported Ag-based plasmonic catalysts [15]. Fig. 7(b) shows the degradation rate of MB with increasing reaction time (blue curve) and the changes of intensity of the SPR peak during this process (red curve). Blue curve shows the degradation rate of MB with the reaction time. It can be seen that MB was almost completely degraded after 170min of visible light irradiation over the Ag/AgHSiW catalyst and during this process, the intensity of the SPR peak of Ag also changes accordingly (inset in Fig. 7(b)). To the best of our knowledge, for those reports on other plasmonic photocatalysts Ag/AgX [15,22,28], no studies focus on the stability of Ag of these catalysts, while this issue is particularly crucial because many catalysts easily deactivate due to their poor stability. As shown by the red curve in Fig. 7(b), it can be seen that with the increase of the reaction time the intensity of the SPR peak first increases rapidly and then reaches a constant. We deduce that the change of the SPR peak intensity reflected the concentration change of the Ag NPs. Specifically, under light irradiation [SiW12O40]4− was reduced to [SiW12O40]5− and then the Ag+ ions were reduced to Ag by [SiW12O40]5−, i.e. Ag+ +e− →Ag, thus leading to the increase of concentration of Ag NPs and the SPR peak also strengthens with it. With the proceeding of the reaction, some high active Ag NPs were oxidized back to Ag+ by the O2 molecules adsorbed on the surface of POMs, i.e. Ag+O2 →Ag+ +O2 −, thus resulting in a reversible reaction between Ag+ and Ag, i.e. Ag+ +e− ↔Ag, in which POMs are highly efficient in storing and shuttling electrons. When the reaction rate of the positive reaction is equal to that of the negative reaction, the SPR peak becomes stable. It should be notable that the SPR peak maintains a small change in intensity during this whole reaction process, suggesting a relative stability and high catalysis activity of the catalyst. This feature is very important for the practical application of the plasmonic catalysts. In this respect, the Ag/AgHSiW catalyst has evident advantages over other reported Ag-based catalysts. Although Ag/AgX have been reported to exhibit excellent photocatalytic activity, the photodecomposition issue of AgX cannot be overcome yet, which greatly limits their practical application. For our catalyst, on the one hand, AgHSiW is photo-stable and inherently has some photocatalytic activity under visible-light irradiation, and on the other hand the photo-reduced ability of POM ions and the confinement effects of POM ions on Ag NPs could ensure the stability of Ag NPs. In addition, the Ag/AgHSiW exhibits strong Brønsted acidities, due to interactions between the protons and the large counter-anion [21]. All these aspects contribute to its advantages over Ag/AgX. 3.5 The stability of Ag/AgHSiW The stability of a photocatalyst is very important for its practical application during long-term use and recycling. In order to investigate the stability of the catalyst, Ag/AgHSiW NPs were repeatedly used under same experimental conditions. As shown in Fig. 8(a), it can be clearly seen that the catalyst exhibited excellent stability and no apparent activity loss was observed even after the fifth cycle, indicating its reusability. Such a high stability is very important for its practical application. In addition, the catalyst after photocatalytic reaction was characterized by resonance light scattering (RLS) in order to further detect the Ag/AgHSiW NPs stability. The RLS measurement was performed under the condition of λ ex = λ em by using fluorescence spectrophotometer. It was found from the RLS spectra (Fig. 8(b)) that before photocatalysis the catalyst exhibits two RLS peaks centered at 340 and 470nm, respectively, which can be ascribed to those of Ag and AgHSiW. While after five cycles of photocatalysis, the RLS spectrum is almost similar to that before photocatalysis and only the peak of 340nm becomes slightly weaker and that of 470nm gets lightly stronger. The possible reason may be that after photocatalysis the concentration of Ag particles decreases and AgHSiW particles grow larger, which is based on Rayleigh's theory [29] that the intensity of scattered light is proportional to the concentration and the third power of radius of particles. Above result confirms once again that the as-synthesized Ag/AgHSiW catalyst is relatively stable and could be reused, which could be solved by further loading. 3.6 Photocatalytic mechanism of Ag/AgHSiW According to IR and TG analysis, we know that there are abundant OH groups on the surface of catalyst; DRS and PL spectrum examination confirmed improved visible light absorption and efficient separation of photo-excited charge carriers, respectively. On the basis of these experimental results, we proposed a plausible catalytic mechanism (Fig. 9(a)). When the AgHSiW is excited by visible light, the photogenerated electrons move to the conduction band (CB) while the photogenerated holes migrate to the valence band (VB). Simultaneously, the Ag NPs generate plasmon-induced hot electrons and holes under visible-light irradiation [14,30]. Subsequently, the plasmon-induced hot electrons are injected into the CB of AgHSiW, while the holes at the VB top of the AgHSiW would migrate to that of Ag. It is because that the CB bottom and VB top of the Ag both lie above those of AgHSiW due to their different potentials. Therefore effective separating of electrons and holes are achieved. Subsequently the electrons are captured by O2 adsorbed on the surface of AgHSiW to form highly active superoxide radical (O2 −). In the other side, the photogenerated holes combine with OH to form OH. Thus the photo-excited charge carriers are readily separated and these h +, OH and O2 − have been proposed as the oxidizing species, which are responsible for the degradation of the organic substrates. Accordingly, the coupling of hot electrons that are formed by the plasmon with the electromagnetic field can effectively increase the probability of a photochemical reaction. In contrast, in the absence of a strong electric field recombination could not be avoided. Excited-state electrons and holes can recombine and dissipate the input energy as heat, get trapped in metastable surface states, or react with electron donors and electron acceptors adsorbed on the Ag/AgHSiW surface or within the surrounding electrical double layer of the charged particles. In the photocatalytic process, photo-induced active species, including h +, OH, and superoxide anion (O2 −), were considered as the main oxidizing species. Terephthalic acid (TPA) fluorescence approach was employed in the present study to monitor the formation of ·OH upon visible light irradiation on the Ag/AgHSiW NPs because TPA can react with OH to form highly fluorescent 2-hydroxyterephthalic acid (HTPA) that can be detected by fluorescence spectroscopy [23,31]. As shown in Fig. 9(b) (inset), significant fluorescent signals of HTPA were observed at 426nm under 312nm photo-excited, in which HTPA resulted from the capture of OH by TPA. By plotting the fluorescent signal intensity over time, the time–signal intensity curve was obtained to depict the involvement of OH in the photocatalytic process (Fig. 9(b)). It can be clearly seen that the fluorescent signal intensity first increases linearly, and then rapidly, finally reaches a steady value with the increase of the reaction time. These results provide the fact that enough OH could be generated via the oxidization of surface-adsorbed OH groups and water by the photoexcited holes. 4 Conclusion A newly-designed visible-light driven plasmonic photocatalyst Ag/AgHSiW was successfully synthesized for the first time based on an improved photoreduction strategy. The Ag/AgHSiW NPs have a strong and broad adsorption in the visible region and a weak PL emission, as well as possess enriched OH groups on the surface. Therefore they show high visible light photocatalytic activity for the photocatalytic degradation of MB aqueous solution. The excellent activity could be attributed to the synergy of photoexcited AgHSiW and plasmon-excited Ag NPs. POM anions have redox ability and photocatalytic activity, whereas Ag NPs could effectively accelerate the separation of electros and holes, both of which contribute to their high activity. The Ag/AgHSiW catalyst is high reactivity and particularly stable in the photocatalytic oxidation reactions and therefore it is a promising and efficient catalyst for practical applications. This work provides some insight into the design of novel POM-based plamonic photocatalysts for enhancing photocatalytic degradation activity of organic pollutants. coredata.dc:description: A newly-designed polyoxometalate (POM)-based plasmonic visible-light catalyst, Ag/Ag x H4−x SiW12O40 (Ag/AgHSiW) nanoparticles (NPs), is prepared by a green photoreduction strategy without the addition of any surfactant. The Ag/AgHSiW NPs, which possess abundant hydroxyl (OH) groups on their surface, has not only significantly enhanced visible spectrum absorption but also reduced photoluminescence (PL) emission. Compared with P25, Ag NPs, H4SiW12O40 (HSiW) and Ag4SiW12O40 (AgSiW), the Ag/AgHSiW photocatalyst shows high photocatalytic activity and stability for the decomposition of methyl blue (MB) under visible light irradiation, which could be attributed to highly synergic effect of photoexcited AgHSiW and plasmon-excited Ag NPs.
coredata.dc:title: A newly-designed polyoxometalate-based plasmonic visible-light catalyst for the photodegradation of methyl blue
